Undead

An undead creature formed of an incomplete primordial vessel, unfit to imprison any Atman, and some additional construct of Mana which, by the rules of the Creation within which it exists, allows it to do so anyway. This construction of Mana is often, but not always, a type of Faux-soul, or the imprisoned soul itself may be a Faux-soul - which is somewhat easier to achieve in most Creations.

The mana mechanics in Marlien which allow for construction of Faux-souls and imprisonment of Atman in unsuitable primordial vessels are typically composed of negative_energy.

Alignment and Sentience

Undead created with a Faux-soul as the core are not typically evil, but they operate only by command, or very base instincts. Some are capable of sustaining themselves without drawing mana from, or otherwise harming others. Those which seek destruction, ruin, bloodshed and suffering do so only by the command of another. The same can largely be said for those where a Faux-soul is attached to a real Atman; while the Faux-soul inevitably restrains sentience of the creature and may be used to manipulate its behaviour, it need not be explicitly evil, and will likely appear vastly more intelligent than one driven purely by a Faux-soul.

An undead creature with a bound Atman unrestrained by any Faux-soul freely obeys the Atman and abides by its alignment.

Murmurings

Corporeal and incorporeal undead are prone to displaying semblances of intelligence, and even memories of the corporeal form, or of an imprisoned atman. While this is most common and pronounced amongst undead bearing a real atman, it also occurs in the simplest undead, which are just a Faux-soul bound to a vessel which, at least in part, once held a real atman. In the latter case, this is possible because the precise memories of a living creature are recorded in the essence of the vessel, not in the atman; the simplest of such memories are not so obfuscated as be completely beyond recovery without the atman, and so the undead creature may manifest habits of the intelligence which once occupied its vessel. Such habits are typically short, strained utterances, particular movements or attachments to objects and places, or apparent reaction to familiar names or objects.
